awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Differentiated Citizenship and the Governance of Land and Everyday Life in the Making of a Global City
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research project investigates the governance of land use and everyday life in the creation of world-class cities, a process predicated on displacement of informally settled residents.  This problem holds important insights worldwide in light of rapid urbanization globally accompanied by accelerated slum growth, land enclosures, and rampant civil unrest. The doctoral student will document and explain why and how some forms of informal land-use practices are criminalized while others are institutionally endorsed or practiced by the state, and how such de/criminalization practices shape the differential status of citizenship and rights to the city among the informally settled urban poor. The project examines how government officials, city planners, global policy makers, land developers, local NGOs and residents collectively contribute to urban governance, transforming the city through spatial expansion and land-use practices. Results will be disseminated through publications and reports accessible to academics as well as government officials, city planners, global policy makers, local NGOs, and residents. Local outreach and dissemination is also planned via presentations and workshops, as well as via a subsequent online forum.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award provides support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

This project uncovers (1) the logic underscoring the city-government-planning complex regarding differential treatment of slum dwellers, how these rationalities evolved, and the consequences for slum dwellers; (2) the subjectivities and associated practices among slum dwellers relative to various axes of difference (class, caste, gender, religion, occupation, language group and type of land use) to de-homogenize this diverse group of actors; and (3) the various views among agents of the city-government-planning complex regarding displacement to de-homogenize the state, which commonly is approached as a monolithic entity.  Methods include a mix of qualitative and quantitative ones, including policy assessment, comparing published land-use plans and actual land-use practices, examination of census data, as well as interviews with residents, NGO workers, and actors at multiple tiers of the city-government-planning complex and collaborative research with slum dwellers. Although this research focuses on Delhi, India to examine how world-class city-making models transform the spatial and socio-economic composition of a city, the project provides new insights regarding issues of social justice in cities worldwide including the United States.

por.por_cntn:
This research provides fresh insights regarding the governance of land use and everyday life in the creation of world-class cities, a process predicated on displacement of informally settled residents. This problem holds important insights worldwide in light of rapid urbanization globally accompanied by accelerated slum growth, land enclosures, and global competition to create world-class cities. This project uncovers (1) multiple and often unrecognized processes of urban displacement both in the central city and the periphery of a city; (2) the subjectivities and associated practices relative to land use and coping with displacement among slum dwellers to de-homogenize this diverse group of actors; and (3) the various views among agents of the city-government-planning complex regarding displacement to de-homogenize the state, which commonly is approached as a monolithic entity. Methods include a mix of qualitative and quantitative ones, including policy assessment, comparing published land-use plans and actual land-use practices, examination of census data, as well as interviews with residents, NGO workers, and actors at multiple tiers of the city-government-planning complex and collaborative research with slum dwellers. Although this research focuses on Delhi, India to examine how world-class city-making models transform the spatial and socio-economic composition of a city as well as the subjectivities among the marginalized, the project provides new insights regarding issues of social justice in cities worldwide including the United States.

This doctoral dissertation research contributes to scholarship and debates on redefining displacement and accumulation, new frontiers of citizenship formation and governance of land and life in the margins of a city. This research redefines displacement as a cyclical, ordinary and dynamic process often operated by the displaced slum dwellers as opposed to the state as generally perceived. The co-PI identifies a form of displacement termed as ‘autogenic displacement’, defined as a continuous process of emotional and spatial displacement of the more poor by the less poor within the same class structure and within the city’s periphery. Going beyond conceptualizations of displacement as a spectacular moment of accumulation by the state in the central city; this research identifies displacement through ‘ordinary’ accumulation in the periphery as the less poor displaced and resettled slum dwellers displace the more poor through a newly constructed regime of informal, illicit land use on plots of land allotted to slum dwellers for use but not ownership rights. Drawing from an intensive 13-month ethnographic research in Delhi and its periphery, this research demonstrates that commodification of land through informal land sales by some displaced slum dwellers reproduces the regime of accumulation in the central city and constructs a dynamic class-based politics in the periphery. This research identifies types of informal land use as a heretofore unrecognized criterion for redefining citizenship. This research shows how Delhi’s city-government planning-complex (CGPC) punishes slum dwellers practicing ‘unproductive’ use of land, confiscating or canceling their allotted plots when left vacant and casting them as ‘improper citizens;’ yet the CGPC endorses ‘productive’ use that mimics regimes of central city accumulation of land through informal land transactions.

This research has led to two papers contributing to displacement studies and redefining right to the city framework in urban theory and practice, which are under review at peer-reviewed journals. Another paper on the discourses of biometrics in governing urban displacement, resettlement, and peripheralization of the marginalized is in progress. The co-PI has initiated a report that will be distributed to local NGOs, urban planners, and local academics in Delhi. The co-PI has introduced three modules in an undergraduate course on “Cities and their Global Spaces” based on the findings from this dissertation research that she will teach in Spring 2019.
